name: balalaika
definition: A Russian musical instrument with a triangular body and three strings that produces sounds similar to those of a mandolin.
description:
The balalaika is a Russian stringed musical instrument of lute family with a characteristic triangular body and three strings.

The balalaika is made in six sizes, from piccolo to double bass, and has a flat back and a triangular table, or belly, that tapers to the fretted neck.

The frets are movable, and there is a small, round sound hole in the narrow end of the belly.

The three strings, usually gut, are end hitched and strung over a violin-like, or pressure, bridge.

They are normally plucked with the fingers, although metal strings are also plucked with a leather plectrum.

The instrument generally has a short sustain, necessitating rapid strumming or plucking when it is used to play melodies.

The instrument was used in folk music but was also employed in large balalaika orchestras in the 20th century.

The basses and contrabasses are so large that need a leg that rest on the floor.

They are often played with leather picks.

facts.name: Balalaikas have 16 to 24 frets
facts.value: Amateur and/or souvenir-style prima balalaikas usually have a total of 16 frets, while in professional orchestra-like ones that number raises to 24.

facts.name: Plectra made from a leather shoe
facts.value: Because of the large size of the contrabass's strings, it is not uncommon to see players using plectra made from a leather shoe or boot heel.

facts.name: Are played with fingers or plectrum
facts.value: The prima balalaika, secunda and alto are played either with the fingers or a plectrum, and the bass and contrabass are played with leather plectra.

facts.name: Balalaikas were originally strung with gut
facts.value: The piccolo, prima, and secunda balalaikas were originally strung with gut with the thinnest melody string made of stainless steel. Today, nylon strings are commonly used in place of gut.

facts.name: Includes instruments of various sizes
facts.value: The balalaika family includes instruments of various sizes, from the highest-pitched to the lowest: the piccolo, prima, secunda, alto, bass and contrabass balalaika.

facts.name: The bass balalaika rest on the ground
facts.value: The bass balalaika and contrabass balalaika rest on the ground, on a wooden or metal pin that is drilled into one of its corners.

facts.name: Use of the left thumb to fret notes
facts.value: An important part of balalaika technique is the use of the left thumb to fret notes on the lower string, particularly on the prima, where it is used to form chords.
